channel.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
channel.description: How do they do it, and is it possible to circumvent it?

item.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:42, topic:144389”]I would tend to disagree with that. Let’s think about it as you are from a business point of view. Ignoring the rather small extra amount of code they must keep and maintain inside the client to support unsigned clients, each and every game server they run must run a webserver, an update server, and a game server. Also the content has to be downloaded every separate instance of the game, this translates into much more work, setting up the extra software and keeping it running, also extra hardware, to support the extra servers running on a machine, and much more bandwidth than would be necessary if only a signed client was available. All of this is required by the unsigned client because, being unsigned, it can only make connections to the server from whence it came.

All of that translates into much more money that jagex spends just to keep an unsigned client available for use, so if ‘8 or 9’ (a small amount) of people used the unsigned client, it would not be monetarily feasible to keep it up and running would it? Therefore it is not unreasonable to assume that many people use the unsigned client, so many that it would not be suspicious to do so.[/quote]

I see where you are coming from. If I understand your argument correctly, I think you are implying that the fact that the case exists implies many instances of the case being utilized. Correct?

You very well could be right. I highly doubt that all of the servers we see as world servers are the actual game servers. The intelligent thing to do would put load-balancing solutions on the boxes running in the DMZ that relay to clusters of servers that run the actual server code. This way they can have many clusters serving a single load-balancer. This would preserve applets’ requirement of same-host connections without sacrificing anything.

I would be very surprised if they did anything different; as it would serve signed and unsigned applets equally.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“semaphore, post:40, topic:144389”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=197929.msg1767183#msg1767183 date=1190220773]
First off, it would be stupid to run runescape as a signed applet because, as it has been said, it can do whatever it wants.
[/quote]

I suppose that would work fine. So you and the 8 or 9 other people that do that will be safe from them executing protected code on your machine. That won’t look suspicious at all… If I were them, I’d closely monitor everything anyone that ran an unsecured client did. I think running an unsecured client gives you less protection from their watch-dogs and not more. It just raises their threat level against you. But if you get a warm-fuzzy thinking you are keeping yourself from being detected by running the unsecured applet, go for it…[/quote]

I would tend to disagree with that. Let’s think about it as you are from a business point of view. Ignoring the rather small extra amount of code they must keep and maintain inside the client to support unsigned clients, each and every game server they run must run a webserver, an update server, and a game server. Also the content has to be downloaded every separate instance of the game, this translates into much more work, setting up the extra software and keeping it running, also extra hardware, to support the extra servers running on a machine, and much more bandwidth than would be necessary if only a signed client was available. All of this is required by the unsigned client because, being unsigned, it can only make connections to the server from whence it came.

All of that translates into much more money that jagex spends just to keep an unsigned client available for use, so if ‘8 or 9’ (a small amount) of people used the unsigned client, it would not be monetarily feasible to keep it up and running would it? Therefore it is not unreasonable to assume that many people use the unsigned client, so many that it would not be suspicious to do so.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
item.dc:creator: @BAsh_CntLgn BAsh(CntLgn)
item.description:
@BAsh_CntLgn wrote:

I would build my own securityManager and check all the calls that go through it.

If unsure (ie. reads from directories other than the cache directory) then I would ask the user.

That way it can be signed and yet still be safe.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
item.dc:creator: @semaphore semaphore
item.description:
@semaphore wrote:

yoursoul:

Dont jagex store random.dat file in your cookies or somewhere, which tells them your ip anyway.

Just… stop. Please find another hobby.

Moparisthebest:

First off, it would be stupid to run runescape as a signed applet because, as it has been said, it can do whatever it wants.

I suppose that would work fine. So you and the 8 or 9 other people that do that will be safe from them executing protected code on your machine. That won’t look suspicious at all… If I were them, I’d closely monitor everything anyone that ran an unsecured client did. I think running an unsecured client gives you less protection from their watch-dogs and not more. It just raises their threat level against you. But if you get a warm-fuzzy thinking you are keeping yourself from being detected by running the unsecured applet, go for it…

Keep in mind, the only real reason for tracking ip addresses is to identify unique machines and/or clients. There’s likely a number of reasons for this. I can promise you that the most important of which has little to do with preventing cheaters or hackers. The number one reason involves advertising. The more unique individuals they can show that play the game, the more they can charge/increase the cost for advertising. Every web-based company with a vested interest in advertising has many eyes on unique page-views.

That said, there is also the side-benefit of detecting known cheaters. All-in-all though, from my experience, these guys care very little about your small hacking/cheating operations and care far more about game stability and advertising dollars/pounds.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Because he set java to use the browser settings, and for some reason firefox doesn’t pass the proxy settings to the java plugin. He either needs to use IE (please no) or set the proxy settings directly in the java console.

Thanks Mopar. It finally works. Now I have to see if it works when the browser proxy is disabled, and if it works on Opera.

Read full topic

item.title: Jagex seeing IP through proxy
item.dc:creator: @xxlegitxx xxlegitxx
item.description:
@xxlegitxx wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Maybe TOR isn’t turned on or something? A socks5 proxy does hide your IP from jagex, I know, I’ve done it before.

Ok. I turn on tor (vidalia + privoxy). The onion in the taskbar is green. So is the privoxy sign.
Control Panel -> Java. Network settings -> Use browser settings.
Firefox -> Options -> Advanced -> Network -> Settings…:
HTTP: localhost:8118
SSL: localhost:8118
SOCKS: localhost:9050
Socks v5.

Is there anything else I should be setting? How do it force java to use the socks5 proxy instead of whatever?

Read full topic

Moparisthebest:

And you can use TOR, I have done it in the past.

I use TOR/JAP, set Java settings as browser settings, log in and log out. I log in, and the previous logged in IP is my current ip.

item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:22, topic:144389”]So I set network settings for Java as a SOCKS5 proxy. No need to set it for my browser?
Then I go to the RS detail page, and select unsigned. I should be undetectably behind a browser then?[/quote]

To be on the safe side set your browser to use the SOCKS5 proxy as well.
